snippet.textDisplay: If you want to learn more about the fascinating, isolated island of St Helena, listen to our podcast Extremities. We spent a whole season covering how St Helena works--its economy, its people, its government, and much more: http://extremitiespodcast.com
snippet.textOriginal: If you want to learn more about the fascinating, isolated island of St Helena, listen to our podcast Extremities. We spent a whole season covering how St Helena works--its economy, its people, its government, and much more: http://extremitiespodcast.com

snippet.textDisplay: What has happened to the people who built the modern world. We cant even build a proper fucking airport these days. I blame merit being tossed out the window. Out of striving for diversity we have elevated people utterly INCAPABLE of developing or engineering things like this. This policy of engineering schools and hiring trickles down and makes us terrible at everything we try to do these days. Equity and diversity quotas will be the absolute END of the west and her dominance of the world.

snippet.textDisplay: It's a commercial disaster. Should never have been built. And yes, it's saved a few lives but at what cost? For £300 million they could have built them a verywell equiped hospital. And don't tell me you can't put a price on a life, yes you can. Insurance companies do it all the time. All those people getting paid to do virtually nothing all day. A terrible waste of taxpayer's money. This video should really be renamed The most useless airport in the world.

snippet.textDisplay: G'day Wendover, Well, you've convined me. We are both retired now and live in Hobart, Tasmania. For us it means a flight to Melbourne then to Perth, then to 'Joberg' and on to St. Helena. A long way to be sure but Aussies are used to that. Most international flights out of Australia are at least 3 hours long. Most are much longer. I'm pretty sure that a sales campaign in Australia would nett St. Helena many Aussie tourists. Perhaps you could mention this to your contacts on the island. Cheers and thanks for a great adventure travel tip! BH
snippet.textOriginal: G'day Wendover, Well, you've convined me. We are both retired now and live in Hobart, Tasmania. For us it means a flight to Melbourne then to Perth, then to 'Joberg' and on to St. Helena. A long way to be sure but Aussies are used to that. Most international flights out of Australia are at least 3 hours long. Most are much longer. I'm pretty sure that a sales campaign in Australia would nett St. Helena many Aussie tourists. snippet.textDisplay:
So British Airways will run completely empty flights, burning fuel just not to lose their time slot on some airports but couldn't be bothered to run some small flight once or twice a week to one of their countries territories just out of a little bit of solidarity. How much would they lose on this? Fucking pennies. It's absurd.
Anyway, now that I'm done watching...What a documentary it was. Absolutely top notch quality content. For free. What a time to be alive.

snippet.textDisplay: I love curiosity stream's last ditch effort to piggy-back on the fame of our favorite "indie" youtube channels.  Sam, I tried nebula, the player sucked. Fix the player and I'll try it again. I need to be able to do more than just change the resolution. I want all the functionality the youtube player has. This means, subtitles, If I so choose, the detachable player hat can sit in the corner, speed settings, in the same increments youtube has finally arrived at, and most importantly I want, right click, STATS FOR NERDS. Not everybody has blazing fast internet all the time. I gotta see what's going on with my network some times. If I gotta go over to youtube to check that it defeats the purpose of using nebula.
snippet.textOriginal: I love curiosity stream's last ditch effort to piggy-back on the fame of our favorite "indie" youtube channels.  Sam, I tried nebula, the player sucked. snippet.textDisplay:
Great documentary. The media response to the airport made me mad though. It’s a reminder of why I almost never watch news on TV, no longer read free metro newspapers or refuse to visit any news websites.

That plus their websites also usually are around 100MB per webpage full of Javascript trackers that slow your device down, video takeover ads on auto-play, clickbait sponsored content and of course sloppy journalism where they just paraphrase crap people say on Twitter.
snippet.textOriginal:

snippet.textDisplay:
I'm confused by this: the island has a median annual income of $12k per year (3:30), the main city is only ~5 miles wide by road at its widest point, and there are 2 cars for every 3 people on the island (license plate numbered 2353 at 4:27 hints at this, and looked up online to get firmer numbers). Most of those cars are also gas-powered. Some ideas to save a ton of money for the Saints:
- Electric scooters might be your best mode of transportation if you're okay standing for 10+ minutes at a time. They cost ~5% of a car to buy and cost much less to operate. Electric bikes are also another excellent option (~15% of the price of a car) and have the added benefit of being capable of towing a small cart when you run to the grocery store. The 5% and 15% are on per-capita basis, assuming everyone on the island has their own scooter or bike.
- By moving to electric scooters/bikes for most transportation, need for cars could drop 10x. At that point, car-sharing is immensely more economical, with needs for only perhaps 300 vehicles for the entire island (around $5k / person of capital investments saved). A block of 10-20 homes would only need perhaps 1 car since the demand would be so limited.
- The reduced car usage would result in less road maintenance costs, saving even more money in local taxes. Many roads could also be built to be smaller in the future if they were "no cars" roads, further reducing costs.
- The saved money could help you double-down on solar and battery for the island (which your island is also doing amazing things with) to save yet even more money over the long term.
- Making the island completely car free (e.g. move to golf carts or light electric vehicles that don't look like cars) could also be fun for tourists (e.g. see Mackinac Island), potentially boosting tourism and island revenue.
- If wanting to keep cars after you move to scooters / bikes for most transport, you'll now only need perhaps 300 cars if you move to a car-sharing program (or an informal one among neighbors where 5-10 homes share a car). Far fewer cars means you have more capital freed for other investments, such as solar, which would be helpful for ...
- If all vehicles were required to be all-electric (could have smaller batteries than normal because the island is so small), they'd all be rechargeable with those solar arrays and cost less over time to maintain, saving people on the island even more money while being nice and quiet in your beautiful town.
- Regarding the right battery to pair with your solar grid, a flow battery might be the right fit, as its potentially lower cost than lithium ion and can be scaled more easily for several days of storage. This should be commercially available by 2021 or 2022 at latest.

My guess is that the median savings could be $2k+ per year with the vehicle changes above -- nearly a 20% boost (effectively) to the local disposable income, since I'm betting Saint Helena is neither a car-manufacturing nor oil-producing economy and so all those purchases are money leaving the island.
snippet.textOriginal:
I'm confused by this: the island has a median annual income of $12k per year (3:30), the main city is only ~5 miles wide by road at its widest point, and there are 2 cars for every 3 people on the island (license plate numbered 2353 at 4:27 hints at this, and looked up online to get firmer numbers). Most of those cars are also gas-powered. Some ideas to save a ton of money for the Saints:
- Electric scooters might be your best mode of transportation if you're okay standing for 10+ minutes at a time. They cost ~5% of a car to buy and cost much less to operate. Electric bikes are also another excellent option (~15% of the price of a car) and have the added benefit of being capable of towing a small cart when you run to the grocery store. The 5% and 15% are on per-capita basis, assuming everyone on the island has their own scooter or bike.
- By moving to electric scooters/bikes for most transportation, need for cars could drop 10x. At that point, car-sharing is immensely more economical, with needs for only perhaps 300 vehicles for the entire island (around $5k / person of capital investments saved). A block of 10-20 homes would only need perhaps 1 car since the demand would be so limited.
- The reduced car usage would result in less road maintenance costs, saving even more money in local taxes. Many roads could also be built to be smaller in the future if they were "no cars" roads, further reducing costs.
- The saved money could help you double-down on solar and battery for the island (which your island is also doing amazing things with) to save yet even more money over the long term.
- Making the island completely car free (e.g. move to golf carts or light electric vehicles that don't look like cars) could also be fun for tourists (e.g. see Mackinac Island), potentially boosting tourism and island revenue.
- If wanting to keep cars after you move to scooters / bikes for most transport, you'll now only need perhaps 300 cars if you move to a car-sharing program (or an informal one among neighbors where 5-10 homes share a car). Far fewer cars means you have more capital freed for other investments, such as solar, which would be helpful for ...
- If all vehicles were required to be all-electric (could have smaller batteries than normal because the island is so small), they'd all be rechargeable with those solar arrays and cost less over time to maintain, saving people on the island even more money while being nice and quiet in your beautiful town.
- Regarding the right battery to pair with your solar grid, a flow battery might be the right fit, as its potentially lower cost than lithium ion and can be scaled more easily for several days of storage. This should be commercially available by 2021 or 2022 at latest.

My guess is that the median savings could be $2k+ per year with the vehicle changes above -- nearly a 20% boost (effectively) to the local disposable income, since I'm betting Saint Helena is neither a car-manufacturing nor oil-producing economy and so all those purchases are money leaving the island.

snippet.textDisplay: This airport, due to its lack of infrequent utilization and regulatory-mandated overhead and large number of staff compared to passenger numbers, seems like a very burdensome ongoing operating expense for this small island. It would seem that a seaplane port (due to much lower cost and flexibility) would have been far more appropriate given the tiny demand for flights. It seems unlikely that the St. Helena airport will ever repay for its construction and operating expenses. I suspect the airport will eventually be closed down due to its unsustainable cost structure.
snippet.textOriginal: This airport, due to its lack of infrequent utilization and regulatory-mandated overhead and large number of staff compared to passenger numbers, seems like a very burdensome ongoing operating expense for this small island. It would seem that a seaplane port (due to much lower cost and flexibility) would have been far more appropriate given the tiny demand for flights. It seems unlikely that the St. Helena airport will ever repay for its construction and operating expenses. I suspect the airport will eventually be closed down due to its unsustainable cost structure.
